description: From Old French ensu- , stem of some conjugated forms of ensivre (“follow close upon, come afterward”) (French ensuivre), from Latin īnsequere, from īnsequi (“to pursue, follow, follow after; come next”), from in- (“upon”) (see in-) + sequi (“follow”) (see sequel).

verbs.description: ensue (third-person singular simple present ensues, present participle ensuing, simple past and past participle ensued)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To follow (a leader, inclination etc.). [15th–17th c.]
examples: to ripenesse of mans state they grew: / Then shewing forth signes of their fathers blood, / They loued armes, and knighthood did ensew, / Seeking aduentures [...].

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To follow (in time), to be subsequent to. [15th–17th c.]
examples: Oh how many changes are like to ensue this reformation!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To occur afterwards, as a result or effect. [from 16th c.]
examples: Give three freshmen six bottles of wine, and hilarity will ensue.
